parts.text: Indicate any changes you’ve made to your Medicaid expansion CHIP programs/policies in the past federal fiscal year. All changes require a State Plan Amendment (SPA).
parts.title: Changes in Medicaid Expansion CHIP Programs and Policies

questions.label: Have you made any changes to the eligibility determination process?
Have you made any changes to the eligibility redetermination process?

questions.hint: For example: increasing the FPL or income levels, or other eligibility criteria.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the eligibility levels or target populations?

questions.hint: For example: adding or removing different types of coverage.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the benefits available to enrolees?
Have you made any changes to the single streamlined application?
Have you made any changes to your outreach efforts?

questions.hint: For example: transitioning from Fee for Service to Managed Care for different CHIP populations.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the delivery system(s)?

questions.hint: For example: changing amounts, populations, or the collection process.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to your cost sharing requirements?

questions.hint: For example: changing substitutions or the waiting periods.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the crowd-out policies?
Have you made any changes to an enrollment freeze and/or enrollment cap?
Have you made any changes to the enrollment process for health plan selection?

context_data.bullet_text: Enrollment process for health plan selection

questions.hint: For example: changing from the Medicaid Fair Hearing Process to state law.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the protections for applicants and enrollees?

questions.hint: For example: adding premium assistance or changing the population that receives premium assistance.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to premium assistance?
Have you made any changes to the methods and procedures for preventing, investigating, or referring fraud or abuse cases?

context_data.bullet_text: Methods and procedures for prevention, investigation, and referral of cases of fraud and abuse

questions.hint: For example: expanding eligibility to pregnant enrollees.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to your prenatal care eligibility?

questions.hint: For example: extending coverage to pregnant enrollees.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to your Pregnant Woman State Plan expansion?
Have you made any changes to eligibility for “lawfully residing pregnant women”?
Have you made any changes to eligibility for “lawfully residing children”?
Have you made any changes to any other program areas?
Anything else you'd like to add that wasn't already covered?
Do you plan to submit a SPA to reflect changes to your programs or policies if you haven’t done so already?

parts.text: Your performance goals should match those reflected in your CHIP State Plan, Section 9. If your objectives or goals are different, submit a State Plan Amendment (SPA) to reconcile these differences.
parts.title: State Plan Goals and Objectives

questions.hint: For example: Our objective is to increase enrollment in our CHIP program.

answer.default_entry: Reduce the number of uninsured children.

Why was this goal discontinued?

subsections.text: Substitution of coverage (also known as crowd-out) occurs when someone with private insurance drops their private coverage and substitutes it with publicly funded insurance such as CHIP.

questions.label: Do you track the number of children who have access to private insurance?
What percent of children who enrolled in CHIP had access to private health insurance at the time of application?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-b-01-01 is no, N/A, or unanswered; noninteractive: hide if that's no or N/A.

questions.label: Do you use a database to match children to their private insurance status?
Which database do you use?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-b-01-02 is no, N/A, or unanswered; noninteractive: hide if that's no or N/A.

questions.label: Does your S-CHIP program require a child to be uninsured for a minimum amount of time before enrollment (“the waiting period”)?
How long is the waiting period?
Which populations does the waiting period apply to?  (Include FPLs for each group.)
What exemptions apply to the waiting period?
What percent of children subject to the waiting period meet an exemption?
What percent of children screened for S-CHIP eligibility cannot be enrolled because they have group health plan coverage?

context_data.skip_text: Some questions omitted because they do not apply to your program.

questions.label: Anything else you’d like to add about crowd-out that wasn’t already covered? Did you run into any limitations when collecting data?

subsections.title: Substitution of Coverage (Crowd-out)

subsections.text: Cost sharing is the share of costs that CHIP enrollees pay out of pocket. Cost sharing can include enrollment fees, premium fees, deductibles, coinsurance, copayments, and any other out-of-pocket costs. States can choose to require cost sharing or not.

questions.label: Does your state require cost sharing?
Who tracks cost sharing to ensure families don’t pay more than the 5% aggregate household income in a year?
What information or tools do you provide families with so they can track cost sharing?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-d-01-02 is anything except families; noninteractive: same.
conditional_display.skip_text: 2a not shown due to your answer to 2.

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-d-01-02 is anything except other; noninteractive: same.

subsections.title: Cost Sharing (Out-of-Pocket Costs)

parts.text: States with a premium assistance program can use CHIP funds to purchase coverage through employer sponsored insurance (ESI) on behalf of eligible children and parents.

questions.hint: Check all that apply.
questions.label: Under which authority and statutes does your state offer premium assistance?
Does your premium assistance program include coverage for adults
Who do you cover?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-e-01-02 is unanswered or no; noninteractive: hide if that's no.

questions.label: How does your premium assistance program operate? How do you coordinate premium assistance with employers? Who receives the subsidy (if applicable)?
Which benefit package is offered as part of your premium assistance program?
Are there any minimum coverage requirements as part of the benefit package?
Does your premium assistance program provide wrap-around coverage for gaps in coverage?
Are there limits on cost sharing for children in your premium assistance program?
Are there limits on cost sharing for adults in your premium assistance program?
Are there protections on cost sharing for children (such as the 5% out-of-pocket maximum) in your premium assistance program?
How do you track cost sharing to ensure families don’t pay more than 5% of the aggregate household income in a year?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-e-01-09 is unanswered or no; noninteractive: hide if that's no.

questions.label: How many children were enrolled monthly in the premium assistance program on average each month in the last FFY?

questions.label: Coverage breakdown for children
What’s the average monthly contribution the state pays towards coverage of a child?
What’s the average monthly contribution the employer pays towards coverage of a child?
What’s the average monthly contribution the employee pays towards coverage of a child?
Coverage breakdown for parents
What’s the average monthly contribution the state pays towards coverage of the eligible parent?
What’s the average monthly contribution the employer pays towards coverage of the eligible parent?
What’s the average monthly contribution the employee pays towards coverage of the eligible parent?
Range in monthly contributions paid by state
What’s the range in the average monthly contribution paid by the state on behalf of a child?
What’s the range in the average monthly contribution paid by the state on behalf of a parent?
Range in family income levels
What’s the range in income levels for children who receive premium assistance?
What’s the range in income levels for children who receive premium assistance?
What strategies have been most effective in reducing the administrative barriers in order to provide premium assistance?
What impact do you estimate your premium assistance program has on enrollment and retention rates? If you’ve measured this impact, how have you done so?
What challenges did you experience with your premium assistance program in the last federal fiscal year (FFY)?
What accomplishments did you experience with your premium assistance program in the last FFY?
Anything else you’d like to add that wasn’t already covered?

subsections.title: Employer Sponsored Insurance and Premium Assistance

parts.text: States with a premium assistance program can use CHIP funds to purchase coverage through employer sponsored insurance (ESI) on behalf of eligible children and parents.

questions.label: Do you have a written plan with safeguards and procedures in place for the prevention of fraud and abuse cases?
Do you have a written plan with safeguards and procedures in place for the investigation of fraud and abuse cases?

What safeguards and procedures do the Managed Care plans have in place? Attach any relevant documents.

questions.label: Have you made any changes to the eligibility determination process?

Do you plan to submit a SPA to reflect changes to your programs or policies if you haven’t done so already?

answer.entry:
[Application]In 2018, the paper application (ACA-3) and the HIX online application were revised to clarify instructions and help text for questions regarding tax filing. In addition, the “sheltered workshop” question was removed as sheltered workshops have been phased out in MA.
[Delivery system]Managed Care options expanded on 3/1/18 to include Accountable Care Organizations.
[Eligibility determination process]MassHealth implemented changes to Reasonable Compatibility rules for verification of income to consider income verified if both self-attested income and income returned from electronic data sources are both under applicable income threshold. This change was implemented to align with changes to provisional eligibility rules and to align to federal requirements.
